title: 111_hr999
content: The "Keeping America's Food Safe Act of 2009" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to include certification of private food safety laboratories and sampling services. In Section 2 of the "Keeping America's Food Safe Act of 2009," private food safety laboratories and sampling services must apply for certification from the Secretary, who will review and grant or deny certification based on established criteria and methodologies. Private food safety laboratories and sampling services must meet specific criteria to obtain certification from the Secretary. This includes accreditation to ISO standards, allowing facility inspections, routine audits for compliance, and submitting a fee with the application. Private food safety laboratories and sampling services seeking certification from the Secretary must meet specific criteria, including accreditation to ISO standards, facility inspections, compliance audits, and submitting a fee with the application. Importers must also agree to submit test results conducted by certified labs or sampling services. The Secretary will establish a process for certified labs to submit test results on behalf of importers. Additionally, importers cannot be federally certified for testing their own products. An importer cannot be federally certified for testing their own food products unless the Secretary establishes a process for certification. Importers who falsify test results from certified labs or sampling services may face a civil penalty of up to $1,000,000. An importer may be subject to a civil penalty of up to $1,000,000 for submitting false test results from a certified food safety laboratory or sampling service. Amendments include changes to paragraph references for clarity and consistency. SEC. 805. CERTIFICATION OF FOOD IMPORTERS. The Secretary will establish a certification program within 2 years to ensure imported food meets US safety standards. Foreign facilities must prove their food meets equivalent safety, inspection, labeling, and consumer protection standards as US-produced food. The certification program will assess the safety of food products exported from foreign countries and evaluate the effectiveness of their food safety programs. Food imports into the US require certification for the facility or country, ensuring equivalence to US safety standards. The Secretary may determine that certification is not needed if the facility or country's standards are equivalent to US standards for food safety, inspection, labeling, and consumer protection. Foreign facilities and countries can obtain certification stating compliance with food safety standards to import into the US. Foreign countries can obtain certification from the Secretary if they have food safety standards equivalent to those in the United States and enforce them effectively. The certification ensures that food products intended for export to the US are safe for consumption and not adulterated or misbranded. Agreements with foreign nations require prompt notification of any issues regarding food safety standards. Foreign countries must notify the Secretary promptly of any safety violations in food products exported to the US. The Secretary can conduct analysis, testing, and sampling at various stages to ensure foreign countries enforce food safety standards equivalent to those in the US. Reciprocity in the treatment of food imports and exports is also required. The Secretary must provide annual documentation to Congress showing confidence in foreign food facilities. Certification for a foreign facility or country can be revoked if linked to illness outbreaks, not meeting requirements, or denying necessary audits by US officials. The Secretary can conduct audits and inspections to ensure compliance with food safety standards for foreign facilities. Certifications are valid for up to 5 years, and audits of foreign countries and facilities must be done at least every 5 years. The Secretary can enforce importation rules for food from foreign countries and facilities by conducting audits and inspections every 5 years. The Secretary is authorized to deny importation if access for audits is denied, if there is a food-borne illness outbreak, or if food is found to be adulterated or mislabeled. Regulations will be promulgated to fulfill the requirements of this section. The Secretary will establish terms and conditions for product destruction that fails to meet standards. A transitional food safety import review program will be implemented within 180 days to ensure minimal disruption to commerce until the food import certification program is in place. SEC. 4. INFORMATION CLEARINGHOUSES. Chapter IV of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include a new section on information clearinghouses. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, will develop and maintain a Website providing information on Federal food standards, best practices for food preparation, assisting health professionals in diagnosing and treating food-related illnesses, and promoting public awareness of food safety issues. The resources of the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control will be utilized. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will develop and maintain a Website providing information on school curricula regarding food safety issues. SEC. 5. WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION. Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to include whistleblower protection. The text prohibits harassment, prosecution, liability, or discrimination against individuals who engage in proceedings related to the Act or refuse to violate it. Procedures for addressing discrimination are outlined, with options for alternative dispute resolution. The text outlines procedures for addressing discrimination, including alternative dispute resolution options like mediation or arbitration. Legal burdens of proof for prohibited discrimination are governed by specific provisions of the United States Code. SEC. 6. REPORTABLE FOOD REGISTRY. The Responsible Parties and Individual Analysis or Test sections of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act are amended to clarify the definition of responsible party and the requirements for establishments analyzing or testing food samples for safety in the United States. The Responsible Parties and Individual Analysis or Test sections of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act are amended to require responsible parties to notify the FDA within 24 hours if any analysis suggests an article of food is reportable, regardless of subsequent findings. Additionally, a conforming amendment clarifies registration requirements for responsible parties. In subsection (a)(1)(A), registration requirements are amended. In subsection (f)(2)(A), the responsibility for registration is clarified. SEC. 7. RECALL AUTHORITY. Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to include violation of a food recall order. Adds a new section 417A for recall authority. "SEC. 417A. RECALL AUTHORITY. The Secretary can request an establishment to recall food if it poses a health risk and the establishment has not initiated a recall. If the establishment does not comply within 24 hours, the Secretary can issue an order for a recall. Definition of 'establishment' is provided. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS." "Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 through 2014 to carry out this Act and its amendments."
